Sure, a start on the side will help with a bad tap system or agitated beer BUT :

1. Those nucleation site are caused by a dirty glass. No matter how you pour it, they’ll still be there. Ask your bartender for a clean glass.

2. Agitating the beer releases aromas which enhance the flavor. No head = bad beer

3. The example they used to demonstrate excessive head appeared to be a stout, which you traditionally pour DOWN THE CENTER OF THE GLASS. Any with some sense never violently dumps their beer in glass.

Well when pouring from a keg, it's important to use this technique. However, with most quality canned and bottled beers, there really isn't much carbonation in them. If you pour gently, you won't get any head at all. If you want head from a bottled beer, you can't just pour the last 10% rough, you need to pour closer to 50% of it rough. I'm used to having minimal head on my beers because of this. I'd like to try doing a side by side test sometime to see if more head is actually helpful.
What about rinsing the glass first to get less foam? Doesn't wetting the glass reduce friction which in turn  makes less foam? That would make even a better beer pour.
"Tingly"?

Let me tell you: you rinse the inside of the glass with cold water so you remove dish soap residue which causes the foam to collapse to quickly. Then you tilt the glass almost to a horizontal position. Just low enough that your liquid is not slosh out of the glass. NEVER let the bottle touch the glass or the already poured in liquid. When the glass is so "full" the liquid would leak over the rim you put the glass straight and add the remaining liquid to get a nice foam crown. If you wait for like 20 to 30 seconds and add another little bit of beer the foam "hardens" a little and you achieve that the foam stands over the rim without leaking down the glass. Perfectly poured beer. #greetingsfrombavaria

They forgot to mention that you need to put some water in the glass making sure it coats the inside of the glass. It allows the beer to slide in easier since it has a buffer between the glass and beer itself. Straight up pouring in a beer without a watered glass is like trying to use a slip and slide without coating it with soap. You get similar results but without that extra bit of slickness, you are going to have a worse time...I like that they took this topic scientifically but they failed to throw in a bit of practical use logic.

Now do make sure you empty the glass of excess water, don't be a goober and leave a bunch of water in the glass and please everyone, do drink responsibly.
Head also protects the beer from reacting with the oxygen in the air, helping taste better longer.

Most commercial beers are charged with CO2 under pressure, rather than by fermentation in the bottle. This avoids having yeast sediment at the bottom of the bottle.

However, as the commercial brewers often collect their CO2 as a reclaimed waste product of fermentation, I suppose calling the CO2 a fermentation product is technically correct.

For anyone in comments saying this is not science, please google Donald A. Glaser and his bubble chamber, it applies the same principle explained in the video in order to detect electrically charged particles and granted Glaser the Nobel Prize in Physics. Knowing how this principle works on beer actually helps you better understand Glaser's bubble chamber, in fact fro decades it was believed that beer had inspired him to create it.

Important note: This is not the appropriate way to pour every beer. Not all beer is carbonated (that is, contains dissolved carbon dioxide). Some beers are nitrogenated, meaning nitrogen is used instead in a similar process. The beer at 1:14 is an example, and the way it is poured is actually the appropriate method to pour most nitrogenated beers as you actually want to release as much gas as possible in such beers because of the different behavior of their head.
The easiest way to identify such beers is the behavior of their bubbles; if you aggressively pour a nitrogenated beer the visible bubbles will appear to flow down instead of up (most of the bubbles are actually flowing up, but the forces of convection combined with the higher viscosity of nitrogenated beers make the bubbles on the outside of the glass, where you can see them, flow downward).
If you pour a nitrogenated beer properly, it will be about 80% head until it has been allowed to "settle" for a minute, which you should always do before drinking one.
Common examples include Guinness and Left Hand Nitro Milk Stout, though not every nitrogenated beer uses the "force pour" method for releasing its gas. Guinness famously used a "widget" for years inside the can, allowing a normal pour, though I'm not sure they still do.

For all you going to be college freshmen in a couple of weeks, the trick is to hold the beer glass as close to the opening as possible (reduces gravity's effect on the drink, meaning it's hitting the glass at a slower speed which means less foam) and to tilt it 30-60 degreesish depending on how much foam you want. You don't want too much foam, but too little foam is also a bad thing.

Nice video. I want to add something to it.
The gas that escapes when you open the can does not come from the beer itself. In the process of filling the can with beer, CO2 is injected at the end to fill up the can right before it gets locked to avoid oxygen from the air entering in contact with the beer. Oxygen is responsible for the aging of the beer, so that way it can last longer :)

This should be called "how to not get head", not "best beer pour."  Most serious beer drinkers that I know don't want a side pour because it keeps too much CO2 in the beer and doesn't make the proper head.  I didn't see any science addressing why creating the head (foam) is bad, because I feel a false assumption was injected before the experiment.  That side pours don't make foam is well understood, that you WANT foam most of the time is what is normally misunderstood.  So this, to me, just repeats a common myth as if it is fact and totally misses what a question about pouring beer would actually be asking.

For those in the comments section that say beer is horrible, please do not say that until you have tried different types of beer. Not all beer is created equal. I never was a beer drinker until I got into ale. Lager is generally too bland and boring for me, although lager can be drinkable. Ale usually has much more complex discernible flavours such as chocolate, citrus, toffee, spice, honey, liquorice etc. which go beyond the sweet bready malt, and bitter hops. I believe this is due to the warm fermentation process where the ale yeast produces aromatic esters. Some ales are oak aged which imparts another layer of interesting flavour. Make sure to check out Innis and Gunn for really great oak-aged ale.
